intro: Lithophragma affine, commonly known as the Alaska rock beauty, is a perennial flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit. The plant features showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and violet, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are hairy and sometimes reddish in color. Lithophragma affine thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine environments.
